SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer. Don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Diet: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ) and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

( ) All questionnaires
( ) Pioneer health conditions
( ) Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
( ) Pioneer housing
( ) Pioneer education and churchwork
( ) Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

"REMINISCENCES OF LIFE ON A HOMESTEAD."

By
Joseph F. Kirkby
Benson, Saskatchewan.

FILING OUR CLAIMS

It was late in May of 1900 that my father and I took homesteads in the Province of Saskatchewan near the town of Arcola.

Before leaving our home in North Dakota we constructed a covered wagon for our trip to the northwest. We also took a second wagon containing settler's effects; i.e., farm machinery and other necessary equipment. The trip by wagon required nine days.

We tried to do some breaking on our homesteads the first year, but found the soil much too dry. In the meantime we hauled logs and poles to be used in the building of our house, which was to be fourteen by eighteen feet.

As there was plenty of wild hay, we cut and stacked it for feed for our animals when we returned the following year.

There was a postoffice about fifteen miles away at New Hope.

Our nearest neighbor lived ten miles distant.

THE SECOND SUMMER

We returned in the summer of 1901 to do the breaking on our homesteads and get the land ready for future crops.

My brother Andrew, who was with us this season, had the misfortune to injure his ankle. It happened when he was feeding the horses. They kicked vigorously at some small pigs and accidently struck Andrew's ankle. For the remainder of the summer he was unable to work on the farm, hence we elected him to the position of chief cook.

We had several bags of oats in our covered wagon. These we used as a mattress for a time; rather a corrugated bed, to say the least, but each night the ridges were leveled off a little more.

We found it somewhat difficult to bake our bread when a strong wind was blowing, as our first stove rested on the ground with only a few poles to break the force of the breeze.

Getting pure, fresh water was a good deal of a problem in those days. We dug a shallow well near a slough and the water that seeped through into the well we used for most purposes. Sometimes we would find a toad or lizard floating around in the well. In that case we dipped out all the water and allowed it to fill with fresh water.

By

Joseph F. Kirkby
Benson, Saskatchewan.

FILING OUR CLAIMS

It was late in May or 1900 that my father and I took homesteads in the Province of Saskatchewan near the town of Arcola.

Before leaving our home in North Dakota, we constructed a covered wagon for our trip to the northwest. We also took a second wagon containing settler's effects; i.e., farm machinery and other necessary equipment. The trip by wagon required nine days.

There was a postoffice about fifteen miles away at New Hope.

Our nearest neighbor lived ten miles distant.

THE SECOND SUMMER

We returned in the summer of 1901 to do the breaking on our homesteads and get the land ready for future crops.

My brother Andrew, who was with us this season, had the misfortune to injure his ankle. It happened when he was feeding the horses. They kicked vigorously at some small pigs and accidentally struck Andrew's ankle. For the remainder of the summer he was unable to work on the farm, hence we elected him to the position of chief cook.

We had several bags of oats in our covered wagon. These we used as a mattress for a time; rather a corrugated bed, to say the least, but each night the ridges were leveled off a little more.

We found it somewhat difficult to bake our bread when a strong wind was blowing, as our first stove rested on the ground with only a few poles to break the force of the breeze.

Getting pure, fresh water was a good deal of a problem in those days. We dug a shallow well near a slough and the water that seeped through into the well we used for most purposes. Sometimes we would find a toad or lizard floating around in the well. In that case we dipped out all the water and allowed it to fill with fresh water.
There was great danger at that time from typhoid fever. Scores of newcomers had died of it, and all the drinking water had to be sterilized by boiling.

In later years the well-drillers found their way into that locality. Some of the wells were three to four hundred feet deep.

One day a stray colt took refuge from the mosquitoes in a nearby sod stable. My father held a pole across the stable door while I put a halter on to the colt. It seemed very tame. We took care of it that summer and left it with our neighbor when we left in the fall.

MOVING IN (Third Summer)

In the spring of 1902 I moved my family onto my homestead in Saskatchewan, Canada.

The government allowed a homesteader to charter a car in which to transport his settler's effects: stock and farm machinery. The men were also allowed to ride in the car all for the small sum of ten dollars.

We loaded the car at Gretna just across the line from our home in North Dakota. The train arrived at Arcola, Saskatchewan three days later.

There we loaded our wagons with supplies and personal effects and started on a thirty-five mile trip to our log house which we had built on our homestead the previous year. It was a little late in the afternoon when we pulled up in front of our home. A dreary outlook, indeed, for my wife and three small children. Fortunately one can't what the future holds in store.

The following day I hired a man to pick stones off the plowed field, and then disked the ground and planted it to wheat. Picking stones off a plowed field is much easier when the ground is moist.

There had been considerable rain that season, causing our sod roof to leak. We covered our beds and furniture with canvas and comforts. The children played underneath the table when the roof leaked. We were so annoyed by this discomfort that I decided to build a frame house.

About this time I had to call a veterinarian to look at my sick horses. He pronounced the disease to be glanders, and told me the horses would have to be shot at once, their remains burned, and the sod stable fumigated. We fumigated by burning straw inside the stable. Sometimes the sod would become ignited.

What was I to do now. No horses and harvest coming on. I had only a few acres of wheat, but could ill afford to lose it. I decided to borrow my neighbor's horses and in return would loan him my binder.

He pronounced the disease to be glanders, and told me the horses would have to be shot at once, their remains burned, and the sod stable fumigated. We fumigated by burning straw inside the stable. Sometimes the sod would become ignited.

What was I to do now? No horses and harvest coming on. I had only a few acres of wheat, but could ill afford to lose it. I decided to borrow my neighbor's horses and in return would loan him my binder.
My neighbor lived ten miles away. There were no roads nor fences, nor telephone poles to guide us, only bleak prairies. In view of this fact, I cut an arm full of willows and drove one into the ground every half mile. This would enable me to find my way home. My neighbor agreed to come the next day and cut the grain.

The oats we kept for feed. Some of the wheat I traded for coal and some for flour. That fall I bought a team of oxen. They cost twenty dollars each and the harness was ten. I planned to use them that winter for hauling, etc., but a bachelor who lived a few miles away had more horses than he cared to feed for the winter, so he loaned me two of them, a pony and a large work horse. I was forced to juggle the bolts on the whittletree in order to throw more weight onto the heavy horse. After that all went along smoothly and I used the team all winter.

When spring planting time came around I had only the team of oxen. They were old and unable to pull the drill. I decided to hitch one of the cows in with them. Thereby I was able to get the ground cultivated and spring planting finished.

You may think it rather strange that I used the cow as a draught animal. The answer is simple. She wouldn't let anyone milk her. I tried it once. In an instant I was sprawling in a ditch ten feet away, hat, milk bucket and milking stool landing on my head in regular order. That old cow would kick the stars out of the sky, I believe. I tried tying her feet when I milked her. She refused to give a drop. That's why she had to go to work.

Along about this time I received a gift of a team of young steers. I was able to use them by hitching them up with the old oxen. One of the steers was balky and would lie down when hitched to the plow, and he would refuse to budge. The only way I could get him up again was by switching him across the nose with a small twig.

My wife's brother brought in a shipment of wild horses from Montana. These were horses that had not been in harness before that time. He let me use a couple that harvest. I also bought a good farm horse in the fall.

As time went on and I had more land under cultivation, I was able to buy more domestic animals, and in a few years had my farm well stocked.

PESTS AND ANNOYANCES

In the early days on the homestead we were compelled to share our meager grain crops with various and sundry pests, for instance, little animals and wild fowl.

The cranes constantly ate the tops off the grain stocks in the fall. Sometimes the workers would hide behind the stocks and shoot a bird or two.

In view of this fact, I cut an arm full of willows and drove one into the ground every half mile. This would enable me to find my way home. My neighbor agreed to come the next day and cut the grain.

The oats we kept for feed. Some of the wheat I traded for coal and some for flour. That fall I bought a team of oxen. They cost twenty dollars each and the harness was ten. I planned to use them that winter for hauling, etc., but a bachelor who lived a few miles away had more horses than he cared to feed for the winter, so he loaned me two of them, a pony and a large work horse. I was forced to juggle the bolts on the whippetree in order to throw more weight onto the heavy horse. After that all went along smoothly and I used the team all winter.

When spring planting time came around I had only the team of oxen. They were old and unable to pull the drill. I decided to hitch one of the cows in with them. Thereby I was able to get the ground cultivated and spring planting finished.

You may think it rather strange that I used the cow as a draught animal. The answer is simple. She wouldn't let anyone milk her. I tried it once. In an instant I was sprawling in a ditch ten feet away, hat, milk bucket and milking stool landing on my head in regular order. That old cow would kick the stars out of the sky, I believe. I tried tying her feet when I milked her. She refused to give a drop. That's why she had to go to work.

Along about this time I received a gift of a team of young steers. I was able to use them by hitching them up with the old oxen. One of the steers was balky and would lie down when hitched to the plow, and he would refuse to budge. The only way I could get him up again was by switching him across the nose with a small twig.

My wife's brother brought in a shipment of wild horses from Montana. These were horses that had not been in harness before that time. He let me use a couple that harvest. I also bought a good farm horse in the fall.

As time went on and I had more land under cultivation, I was able to buy more domestic animals, and in a few years had my farm well stocked.

PESTS AND ANNOYANCES

In the early days on the homestead we were compelled to share our meager grain crops with various and sundry pests, for instance, little animals and wild fowl.

The cranes constantly ate the tops off the grain stocks in the fall. Sometimes the workers would hide behind the stocks and shoot a bird or two.
Wild geese and ducks flew in from the slough every morning to feed on the grain. Crows became so much of a nuisance that the government offered a bounty of one cent a crow's egg and one and a half cents for crow's feet.

Badgers came for their share of food. They dug deep holes in the ground, causing a great deal of annoyance and loss of time to the workers as the binder wheels became lodged in the openings. The jumping deer, a small type of deer from the mountains, fed regularly in the fields. Foxes and wolves were fearless and came close to the buildings where they would snatch up a chicken or duck and make off with it.

Pocket gophers filled their pockets with grain and stored it away for the winter. There was a bounty of two cents a tail on pocket and prairie gophers. The boys shot gophers on the way to school to get a little extra money.

My wife took the children to school. The old horse became so accustomed to stopping when a gopher hole was in sight that he soon began to stop of his own volition, thereby giving the children a sudden jolt that threw them from the buggy seat.

Occasionally my wife would shoot a skunk that was lurking too close to the chicken house.

One evening as I walked along the path a muskrat took a vicious nip at my shin.

The wolves gave us considerable trouble by stealing our meat and other supplies from the store house. As the government paid a bounty of seven dollars each, I decided to catch some of the culprits, so I set out a piece of poisoned meat. In less than an hour I was enriched by one wolf hide.
